answer_html: Notice the dimension of \(W^\bot\) is the same as that of W.
answer_latex:
Notice the dimension of $W^\bot$ is the same
as that of \emph{W}.
hints_html: Are all three of the vectors linearly independent? If not, what is the dimension (and basis) of W. What will the dimension of the basis of \(W^\bot\) be?
hints_latex:
Are all three of the vectors linearly independent? If not, what is the
dimension (and basis) of W. What will the dimension of the basis of
$W^\bot$ be?
hints_raw: Are all three of the vectors linearly independent?  If not, what is the dimension (and basis) of W.  What will the dimension of the basis of <math>W^\bot</math> be?
sols_html:
We first note that there is a relationship between the three vectors, namely \(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ \end{array} \right] + 2 \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \\ \end{array} \right]\). Thus, we get that W has dimension 2 and thus \(W^\bot\) is also 2 dimensional. Let V be the matrix of basis vectors to W,

\[\begin{aligned} V=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1\\ 1 & 1\\ 0 & 2\\ \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

If \(\displaystyle {}x=[a,b,c,d]^T\) is a basis vector to \(W^\bot\) then orthogonality tells us that

\[\begin{aligned} V^Tx&=0\\ \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a\\ b\\ c\\ d \end{bmatrix} &=\mathbf{0}\end{aligned}\]

Computing this we get the following relationships

\[\begin{aligned} a+c&=0\\ b+c+2d&=0\end{aligned}\]

Since the dimension (or rank) of V is two we will have two free parameters (let’s choose a and d) and so we get that

\[\begin{aligned} c&=-a\\ b&=-2d-c=-2d+a\end{aligned}\]

and finally that

\[\begin{aligned} x= \begin{bmatrix} a\\ -2d+a\\ -a\\ d \end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ -1\\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + d\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ -2\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the two orthogonal vectors \(\left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & -1 & 0 \\ \end{array} \right] , \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 0 & -2 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right]\) are a basis for \(W^\bot\). Notice the dimension of \(W^\bot\) is the same as that of W.
sols_raw:
We first note that there is a relationship between the three vectors, namely <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 
\end{array} \right]  = \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 
\end{array} \right] + 2 \left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
0 & 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 
\end{array} \right]   </math>. Thus, we get that ''W'' has dimension 2 and thus <math> W^\bot</math> is also 2 dimensional. Let V be the matrix of basis vectors to W,

:<math>
V=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0\\
0  &  1\\
1  &  1\\
0  &  2\\
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

If <math>\displaystyle{}x=[a,b,c,d]^T</math> is a basis vector to <math>W^\bot</math> then orthogonality tells us that

:<math>
\begin{align}
V^Tx&=0\\
\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  0  &  1  &  0\\
0  &  1  &  1  &  2
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
a\\
b\\
c\\
d
\end{bmatrix}
&=\mathbf{0}
\end{align}.
</math>

Computing this we get the following relationships

:<math>
\begin{align}
a+c&=0\\
b+c+2d&=0
\end{align}
</math>

Since the dimension (or rank) of V is two we will have two free parameters (let's choose ''a'' and ''d'') and so we get that

:<math>
\begin{align}
c&=-a\\
b&=-2d-c=-2d+a
\end{align}
</math>

and finally that

:<math>
x=
\begin{bmatrix}
a\\
-2d+a\\
-a\\
d
\end{bmatrix}
=
a\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1\\
-1\\
0
\end{bmatrix}
+
d\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
-2\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Therefore the two orthogonal vectors <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 1 & -1 & 0 \\  \end{array} \right] , \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 0 & -2 & 0 & 1 \\  \end{array} \right] </math> are a basis for <math>W^\bot</math>.  Notice the dimension of <math>W^\bot</math> is the same as that of ''W''.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} W = \text{span}\left\{ \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] \right\}\end{aligned}\]

Find a basis for the orthogonal complement \(W^\bot\) of W.
